Hello Terriers!

All of the school districts in Hillsdale County, including the Litchfield Terriers, will be delaying the opening of school until Tuesday, September 8, 2020.

By delaying the start of school we are hoping to see a decrease in statewide infections. Delaying will also give us an extra two weeks to plan and prepare to provide the healthiest learning environment possible.

This was a difficult decision to make, but every Superintendent in the County believes that this was the right decision for us.

We will continue to provide updates to keep you informed of the changes that are taking place. You can email me at mcorey@litchfieldschools.com, or call me on my cellphone at 517-250-2220.

GO TERRIERS!!!

Mike Corey
Superintendent of Litchfield Schools

Senior Spotlight: Brady Brown

Brady Brown is the son of Jack Brown and Carmen Raymond. At LCS Brady has been involved in basketball, football, track, baseball, and NHS. An accomplishment he is proud of is that he kept up with most of his work and that he is graduating. He has too many favorite memories at LCS, but the one that sticks out the most was the nice days that he got to go outside and be on the track with his class. After high school, Brady plans to enter the workforce. Then after a year or two he will consider going to college to be a civil engineer. In ten years, Brady sees himself having a good paying job with a family, his own vehicle, and a house. He admires Breanna Sheffer because she is always there for him. He would like to be remembered as the kid who didnt like giving up even though he always said he wanted to. If you give up, then whats the point to everything youve accomplished on your way up.

Hunter is the son of Robert and Paula Duke. Hunter is involved in National Honor Society, Student Council, Hillsdale County Early Middle College, Basketball and Football. One accomplishment Hunter is proud of is being selected and awarded the DAR Good Citizenship Award. His favorite memories at LCS include winning his first football game and being basketball league champions for the first time in 26 years. After high school, and his fifth year of Early Middle College, he would like to transfer to Kellogg Community College and complete their Physical Therapy Assistants Program, and then work as a PTA. In 10 years, Hunter sees himself successfully working in the field of physical therapy and having a family of his own. He admires Mike Langhann for balancing so many responsibilities and motivating himself to push his limits. Hunter would like to be remembered as an open-minded, dedicated, helpful person with a passion for encouraging humility and unity to those around him.

TERRIER BOYS EARN FIRST TITLE IN 26 YEARS!

The Litchfield Boys won their 6th straight game with a 66-44 victory over Tekonsha. The team went a perfect 6-0 in Division play to claim the SCAA Central Division Title. The team is now 10-8 on the season.

Senior Owen Signor led the way with a game high 27 points and 9 rebounds. Hayden Duke added 10 points and Hunter Duke had a Double Double with 10 rebounds and 11 assists . He now has 149 assists on the season with a 8.1 apg average. He is currently the State of Michigan's leader in that category on Max Preps. Also scoring for Litchfield was Taten Combs 8, Hunter Spieth 6, Chase Rose and Tristan Morton 4, Hunter Duke 3 and Ian Pedroza 2 points. The team was 21/35 on 2 point field goals and 9 of 11 from the free throw line.

The Jv Team also won the Division Title and is now 10-5 on the season.
